column2: A frail, robed man is led into your throne room, and your guards explain that he just arrived on a ship coming from foreign lands. The man would only speak your name over and over again, and so he was brought to you. To your horror, you recognize him at last as [From.GetTitledFirstName]!
column3: Un homme frêle et vêtu d'une robe est mené dans votre salle du trône et vos gardes expliquent qu'il vient tout juste de débarquer d'un navire en provenance des Cités Libres. L'homme répétait inlassablement le même mot : votre nom. Vous frémissez d'horreur en le reconnaissant, c'est [From.GetTitledFirstName] !
column4: Ein gebrechlicher, berobter Man wird in Euren Thronsaal geführt und Eure Wachen erklären, dass er gerade mit dem Schiff von Miklagard eingetroffen ist. Der Mann sprach nur wieder und wieder Euren Namen, daher wurde er zu Euch gebracht. Voller Erschrecken erkennt Ihr ihn schließlich als [From.GetTitledFirstName]!
column6: Un hombre frágil vestido con túnica es conducido a tu sala del trono, y tus guardias explican que acaba de llegar en un barco procedente de Miklagård. El hombre sólo dice tu nombre una y otra vez, y por eso lo han llevado a ti. Para tu horror, ¡lo reconoces por fin como [From.GetTitledFirstName]!

column2: [From.GetTitledFirstName] has finally returned home after a long and successful career as a mercenary! He fought in several battles, and learned much from the clever strategies and tactics favoured by many foreign lands.
column3: [From.GetTitledFirstName] est finalement de retour au bercail après une fructueuse et longue carrière comme épée-louée ! Il a pris part à plusieurs batailles et a beaucoup appris sur les adroites stratégies et les tactiques utilisées par les habitants des Cités Libres.
column4: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist nach langer und erfolgreicher Karriere in der Warägergarde endlich heimgekehrt! Er hat in vielen Schlachten gefochten und vieles von den schlauen Strategien und Taktiken der Griechen und ihrer Feinde in Serkland erfahren.
column6: ¡[From.GetTitledFirstName] por fin ha vuelto a casa después de una larga y exitosa carrera en la Guardia varangian_traita! Luchó en varias batallas, y aprendió mucho de las inteligentes estrategias y las tácticas preferidas tanto por los griegos como por sus enemigos en Serkland.

column2: [From.GetTitledFirstName] has returned from foreign lands after his service with the mercenary company, but he refuses to speak of his experiences there. You know he took part in several battles and killed many foes, but instead of revelling in the glory of his accomplishments, [From.GetFirstName] is plagued by nightmares and jumps at sudden sounds.
column3: [From.GetTitledFirstName] est de retour des Cités Libres et de sa Compagnie d'épées-louées, mais refuse de parler de son expérience là-bas. Vous savez qu'il a pris part à plusieurs batailles et qu'il a eu raison de nombreux ennemis, mais au lieu de raconter ses glorieux exploits, [From.GetFirstName] fait des cauchemars toutes les nuits et sursaute au moindre bruit.
column4: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist aus Griechenland und der Warägergarde zurückgekehrt, aber er weigert sich, von seinen Erlebnissen zu sprechen. Ihr wisst, dass er an etlichen Schlachten teilgenommen und viele Feinde erschlagen hat, doch statt seine glorreichen Erfolge zu feiern, wird [From.GetFirstName] von Alpträumen geplagt und erschreckt bei plötzlichen Geräuschen.
column6: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ha regresado de Grecia y de la Guardia varangian_traita, pero se niega a hablar de sus experiencias allí. Tú sabes que participó en varias batallas y mató a muchos enemigos, pero en vez de deleitarse en la gloria de sus logros, [From.GetFirstName] está plagado de pesadillas y salta con los ruidos repentinos.

column2: [From.GetTitledFirstName] has come home from foreign lands after his service with the mercenary company, but he is not alone. He has found an exotic wife and brought her with him. She is not familiar with our customs or language, and the climate does not seem to agree with her, but she seems willing to make the best of her new home.
column3: [From.GetTitledFirstName] est de retour des Cités Libres et de son service dans une compagnie d'épée-louée, mais il ne revient pas seul. Il s'est marié à une femme exotique qu'il a ramené avec lui. Elle n'est pas habituée à nos coutumes et à notre langue, et ne semble pas apprécier notre climat, mais elle semble vouloir faire d'ici son chez soi.
column4: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist aus Miklagard und seinem Dienst in der Warägergarde heimgekehrt. Er hat eine griechische Braut gefunden und mitgebracht. Sie kennt unsere Gebräuche und Sprache nicht und das Wetter hier scheint ihr nicht gut zu tun, doch sie ist willig, das Beste aus ihrem neuen Heim zu machen.
column6: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ha llegado a casa de Miklagård y de su servicio con la Guardia varangian_traita, pero no está solo. Ha encontrado una esposa griega y la trajo con él. Ella no conoce nuestras costumbres ni el idioma, y el clima no le gusta demasiado, pero parece estar dispuesta a hacer lo mejor de su nuevo hogar.

column2: After many years in foreign lands, [From.GetTitledFirstName] has finally been released from his service to the mercenary company and returned home. Your son is a changed man, however. [From.Religion.GetName] no longer hold any interest for him, and he instead speaks incessantly of a Lord of Light and the horrors that await those who refuse to convert...
column3: Après plusieurs années dans les Cités Libres, [From.GetTitledFirstName] a enfin été dégagé de ses fonctions dans sa compagnie d'épées-louées et est rentré au bercail. Votre fils est cependant un homme changé. [From.Religion.GetName] ne l'intéressent plus et il parle sans cesse du Maître de la Lumière et des horreurs qui s'abattront sur ceux qui refusent de se convertir...
column4: Nach vielen Jahren in Griechenland, wurde [From.GetTitledFirstName] endlich aus seinem Dienst in der Warägergarde entlassen und ist heimgekehrt. Doch Euer Sohn ist ein gewandelter Mann. Die alten Götter interessieren ihn nicht länger, stattdessen spricht er ununterbrochen vom Christentum und den Schrecken, die jene erwarten, die nicht konvertieren...
column6: Tras muchos años en Grecia, [From.GetTitledFirstName] ha sido finalmente liberado de su servicio a la Guardia varangian_traita y ha regresado a casa. Sin embargo, tu hijo ha cambiado. Los viejos dioses ya no le interesan, y en cambio habla sin cesar de la Cristiandad y los horrores que le esperan a aquellos que se niegan a convertirse...

column2: [From.GetTitledFirstName] has returned from foreign lands and his service to the mercenary company as a changed man. He is wiser, more confident in his own abilities and more knowledgeable in matters of war. It seems the time spent abroad did him good.
column3: [From.GetTitledFirstName]est de retour des Cités Libres et de sa compagnie d'épées-louées et c'est un homme changé. Il est plus sage, plus sûr de lui et connaît très bien l'art de la guerre. Le temps qu'il a passé là-bas semble lui avoir fait du bien.
column4: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist als gewandelter Mann aus Miklagard und dem Dienst in der Warägergarde zurückgekehrt. Er ist weiser, zuversichtlicher und besitzt neue Kenntnisse in Kriegsangelegenheiten. Es scheint, als habe ihm die Zeit bei den Griechen gut getan.
column6: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ha vuelto de Miklagård y de la Guardia varangian_traita como un hombre cambiado. Es más sabio, más seguro de sus propias habilidades y más eficiente en asuntos de guerra. Parece que el tiempo pasado en Grecia le ha hecho bien.

column2: Several former mercenaries have recently returned home after serving in foreign lands, and they bring news most grave. Your son, [From.GetTitledFirstName], fell in battle while campaigning. They assure you that he faced his enemy with bravery and slew many before their numbers overwhelmed him.
column3: Plusieurs anciennes épées-louées sont de retour de leur service dans els Cités Libres depuis peu et ils apportent de mauvaises nouvelles. Votre fils, [From.GetTitledFirstName], est tombé au combat lors d'une campagne dans les Terres Disputées. Ils vous assurent qu'il a affronté l'ennemi avec bravoure et qu'il en a tué plusieurs avant qu'ils aient eu raison de lui.
column4: Einige frühere Waräger Gardisten sind von ihrem Dienst beim Griechenkönig heimgekehrt und bringen schlechteste Neuigkeiten mit. Euer Sohn [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist in einer Schlacht in Serkland gefallen. Sie versichern Euch, dass er seinem Feind mit Tapferkeit begegnet ist und viele erschlug, bevor ihre schiere Zahl ihn überwältigte.
column6: Varios ex guardias varangian_traitos han regresado recientemente a casa después de servir al rey Griego, y traen noticias graves. Tu hijo, [From.GetTitledFirstName], cayó en la batalla mientras estaba de campaña en Serkland. Te aseguran que se enfrentó a su enemigo con valentía y que mató a muchos antes de que sus números lo abrumaron.

column2: [From.GetTitledFirstName] has at last returned from foreign lands on a ship filled with the spoils of war! Apparently the rulers from foreign lands are generous to those who serve them well, and there is gold here from all places from Hispania to India. Your son insists on sharing these riches with you, his loving father, for the benefit of House [Root.GetOnlyDynastyName].
column3: [From.GetTitledFirstName] est enfin de retour deCités Libres, à bord d'un navire contenant un impressionnant butin de guerre ! Les Grands Magistrats des Cités Libres sont apparemment très généreux avec ceux qui les servent bien, et il y a de l'or partout, de Braavos à Volantis. Votre fils insiste pour partager ses richesses avec vous, son père bien-aimé, pour le bien de la maison [Root.GetOnlyDynastyName].
column4: [From.GetTitledFirstName] ist endlich aus Griechenland heimgekehrt, auf einem großen Beiboot, gefüllt mit Kriegsbeute. Offenbar ist der Griechenkönig großzügig gegenüber jenen, die ihm gut dienen. Hier findet sich Gold aus allen Ecken Griechenlands, Serklands und darüber hinaus. Euer Sohn besteht darauf, den Reichtum mit Euch, seinem Vater, zu teilen.
column6: [From.GetTitledFirstName] por fin ha regresado de Grecia en un drakkar lleno de botines de guerra! Al parecer, el gran rey de los Griegos es generoso con los que le sirven bien, y hay oro aquí de todas partes del reino griego, Serkland y más allá. Tu hijo insiste en compartir estas riquezas contigo, su querido padre.

column2: Upon learning of the death of your father, you left the mercenary company and foreign lands for home on a ship filled with loot from your campaigns. It was a long and perilous journey back, but your feet are now firmly planted on the soil of the land that is your birthright. The throne is yours.
column3: Après avoir appris la mort de votre père, vous avez abandonné la compagnie d'épées-louées et quittez les Cités Libres sur un navire pour rentrer au bercail, rapportant un important butin amassé lors de vos campagnes. Le voyage du retour fut long et périlleux, mais vos pieds foulent maintenant la terre ferme, cette terre dont vous êtes l'héritier. Le trône est à vous.
column4: Als Ihr vom Tod Eures Vaters erfahrt, verlasst Ihr die Warägergarde und Miklagard in einem großen Beiboot, gefüllt mit der Beute Eurer Schlachten in Serkland. Es war eine lange und gefahrvolle Reise, doch jetzt setzt Ihr Eure Füße auf heimatliche Erde, dir Euer Geburtsrecht ist. Der Thron gehört Euch.
column6: Al enterarte de la muerte de tu padre, dejas la Guardia varangian_traita y dejas Miklagard para volver a casa en un drakkar lleno de botines de tus campañas en Serkland. Fue un largo y peligroso viaje de regreso, pero tus pies están ahora firmemente plantados en la tierra que es tu patrimonio. El trono es tuyo.

column2: Yes, there's a suitable candidate at court.
This heavily fortified collection of shipyards and armories is nothing less than an industrial complex centered around the docks of the Republic's capital.
column3: Ce regroupement très fortifié de chantiers navals et d’armureries n’est rien d’autre qu’un complexe industriel centralisé autour des quais de la capitale de la République.
column4: Diese schwer befestigte Ansammlung von Werften und Waffenkammern ist nicht weniger als ein industrieller Komplex rund um den Hafen der republikanischen Hauptstadt.
column6: Este conjunto fortificado de astilleros y armerías es todo un complejo industrial situado en torno a los muelles de la capital de la República.

column2: [From.Spouse.GetBestName] has discovered your affair with [From.Spouse.GetHerHis] spouse, [From.GetBestName] and is very angry with you.
Selling a prisoner into slavery will cause you to be viewed as a tyrant.
Expelled East African pagan holy order

Our revered ancestors fought to forge a world shaped in their image and shed their blood on the altar of their sacred cause. Their ancient exploits are nothing but legend now, and a great darkness has descended upon the realms of Man. Where are the titans of old now? Where is Alexandros, where is Seleukos, where is Kurus, where is Caesar? Can you remember their deeds and make their spectres bow their heads before you, in approval of your mighty leadership? Can you unite the bickering, warring realms of Man and forge an Empire as the world has never seen? Can you be the Restorer of the Realm of Light and banish the Darkness? Lux Invicta!
This character died while attempting to escape from a siege.
[From.GetTitledFirstName] has refused to accept your duel challenge.
Lux Invicta covers only one start date, but there are plenty of interesting realms in it, here we present a select few ones...

Since Aristotle’s scholarly essays and Megas Alexandros' world empire, the legendary splendours of the East have shaped the Western princes' exotic dreams of mysticism and conquest. In spite of centuries of Hellenistic rule from the Egypt to Kathay, the East still stands untamed. Beyond the Northern steppes, beyond the high passes of the Hindu Kush and the burning deserts of Arabia, history itself takes another meaning, as civilizations strive to revive a Golden Age, older than Rome itself. Their spirituality defies souls and minds, as metaphysical constructions intertwine sensuality with boundless violence as well as audacious intellectual speculations. The ruthless nomads of the Eastern Steppes, eternal enemies of architects and farmers, loom as a Damocles sword over old states that are long past their natural lifespan. The eastern splendours remain a fantasy as always, but they may well become living nightmares for corrupt kings of decadent empires.

Since Aristotle’s scholarly explorations and Megas Alexandros' world empire, the legendary splendours of the East have shaped the Western princes' dreams of exoticism, mysticism and conquests. In spite of centuries of Hellenistic rule from the Mediterranean to the Seas of Kathay, the East still stands untamed. Beyond the Northern steppes, beyond the high passes of at Roof of the World and the burning deserts of Arabia, history itself takes another meaning, as civilizations strive to revive a Golden Age, older than the foundation of Rome itself. Their spirituality defies souls and minds, as metaphysical constructions intertwine refined sensuality with boundless violence as well as audacious intellectual speculations. The ruthless nomads of the Eastern Steppes, eternal enemies of the architect and the farmer, loom as a Damocles swords over old states that have long overpassed their natural lifespan. The eastern splendours remain the fantasy they have always been, but they may well become a living nightmare for corrupt kings of decadent empires.
Proud Emperor of Serindia, decided to restore it's ancient glory at all costs.
A powerful Komi warlord, rallying the tribes with intent to assault the civilized world.
The dreaded Khan of the Huns. A cruel and zealous man who fully believes to be Ahriman incarnated, prepared to scourge the servants of the Great Opponent.
The merchant lord of Kashgar. A competent statesman and shrewd trader. Not the best adherent of the Confucian principles.
The Caliph of Baghdad, a great Islamic scholar, but otherwise a weak leader. Under him, the Abbasid remnant is in constant turmoil.
The Mukarrib of Saba, an isolationist, disliked by merchants due to high commerce taxes, and by his younger brother.

Persia showed the way to all. We remember. Persia built the most solid, glorious and enduring empire. Persia worshipped Ahura Mazda's holy fire altars long before the Western Rumi barbarians understood the immanent truth of Divine Light. Our holy fires may now be shattered by fake creeds, our temples in rumble, our empire split between ambitious liers. But Truth will prevail against the realm of Lies. Once more, Persia shall lead men to glory and salvation!

Persia showed the way to all. We remember. Persia built the most solid, glorious and enduring empire. Persia worshipped Ahura Mazda's holy fire altars long before the Western Rumi barbarians understood the immanent truth of Divine Light. Our holy fires may now be shattered by competing creeds, our temples in rumble, our empire split between ambitious liers. But Truth will prevail against the realm of Lies. Once more, Persia shall lead men to glory and salvation!
The Persian King of Kings. A resolute young man, who is succeeding in carrying his empire out of it's dark age as the true blood of Sassan, heir to most glorious Persian dynasty.

Long before the Sassanid usurpers took the throne, the Arsacids ruled over Persia. Enlightened by the revelations of Mazdak, moved by the desire to cleanse the world from injustice, the heirs of Artaxshasa shall rule again and usher in a new age where all men shall be brothers.

Since Sassan took over the Persian throne from Ardavan VI, our forebearer, using lies and treachery, the Parthians have been biding their time. The Artabanids may have lost worldly power and taken refuge in the Northern desolations, they know who is the true Lord and side with Him. The bitterness of humiliation is sour but sweet are the promises for revenge brought to us by Angra Mainyu, Lord of Darkness.

India and Iran have always had close links, dating from the ancient time when Iranians came from the Indus valley to conquer the Persian plateau. More recently, trade, a force as powerful as swords and gods, has given this link a new vector, generating a fusion culture on the shores of the Indian Ocean. Will the ruler of Zorastrian-Hindu Patala succeed in reinvigorating Persia thanks to the syncretical learnings of the sister millenia-old civilization, India?

Central Asia is home to the oldest forms of Iranian spirituality. It is where the Prophet Zoroastre lived and preached. But it is also in Central Asia, the crossroad of Eurasia, that Persian spirituality met other religious systems and gave birth to innovative syncretisms. The Ephaestionos dynasty of Kârmânia Satrapes have merged the old spiritual enemies of Zoroastrianism and the Hellenistic religion into a harmonious yet potent new system, Pyromantism. May this provincial medium power succeed in redefining Persia based on this new faith, born from the Central Asia spiritual melting-pot?

Persia's spirituality is not exclusively about Zoroastre's teachings and its offsprings. Persia is also the centre of the far-reaching "Church of the East", resulting from the relocation of the School of Edessa to Nisibis. Under Sassanid patronage, Nestorianism has won the souls of Kathay emperors and steppe Kaghans. With the current chaotic situation, is it not the right time for Bukharan Nestorians to claim Persia itself as the new Rome?

§Y'To reach the ends of the world and the Great Outer Ocean, at the head of my army.’§! The dream of Megas Alexandros still echoes through the ages, in the halls and temples of the Hellenistic lands, in the words of would-be conquerors and in the blood of his descendants. Even if weakened, the realms founded by the Diadokhoi, Alexandros’ Successors, generals and loyal companions, still stand proud from Makedonia to India. Though they all share a language and similar culture, over time the claims and counter-claims of legitimacy have deepened the rivalry between the Successors, all claim to be true Greeks, and each also claim to be the one true inheritors of the legacy of the legends of old: of Megas Alexandros, Ptolemy Soter and Seleukus Nikator. This legacy though, belongs to only the strongest...

This legacy though, belongs to only the strongest...

Philippos is the head of the Argeads, main descendants of Alexander the Great through Alexandros IV. Ruler of the Island Kingdom of Cyprus, Philippos is a boisterous, loud and burly person. A strong man, built for combat, yet he lacks any real talent for war. He is married to the charming (insertdiadochiprincess), who has given him a sole male heir, Craterus. Philippos has no other ambitions than his banquets and military competitions, yet the blood of the Conqueror is restless in the veins of his son, who tires of his father's self-indulging ways...

A man whom his troops call "Megas Alexandros reborn", Dorotheos is a famous Rhomaion general who has recently risen against the Empire, throwing the weakened realm into a great crisis. His line, the Argeadai, are descendants of Alexander the Great's illegitimate son Cassander. A proud, charismatic and passionate man, though some would see him as preposterous and overbearing, Dorotheos is prone to give great speeches about the glory of conquest, the bonds of men, and above all, the importance of leaders as active examples to their people, not distant rulers, secluded in their own high ideals. The dream of Dorotheos is the dream of his famed ancestor, to conquer all the worlds at the head of his army, and reach the shores of the Outer Ocean...

Mighty Apollonios, beloved of Apollo Phoibos and true Pharaoh of Aigyptos, rules from his capital at the last Hellenistic stronghold of Kyrene, a realm which combines the grandeur of the ancient world with the sophistication of the new age. Apollonios follows the ancient royal tradition of marrying only within his own family, and has taken his sister Cleopatra for wife, for only such a union can be blessed by the light of Helios! However, the power once bestowed upon the scions of Ptolemy over the Nile has waned and their lands are occupied by all kinds of rivals: imposters claiming Ptolemaic descent, the deluded Argeadai occupying Alexandria and the quarrelsome remnants of the Caliphates. But Aigyptos, under its legitimate rulers, the trueborn Ptolemaic Pharaohs, could even rise beyond the heights of its former supremacy!
Once, the sons of Seleukos sat at Babylonia, the epicentre of civilization, and commanded the greatest empire since Alexander's. He is too deep into Antiocheia's corruption and decadent lifestyle.
Governor of Krete, and descendant of Antigonus the One-eyed. A frustrated man with great ambitions, and no means to carry them out.
The Hellenistic Basileus of India, a foolish man. Supposedly a living buddha, he's anything but that. Not the brightest bulb in the lot, but he absolutely thinks he's.

Ah, the Eternal City! At its greatest extent, the Empire of the Romans stretched from Mesopotamia to the coasts of the Atlantic, encompassing many lands and its peoples, all beholden to the greater idea of Rome. However, its glory is now divided and scattered, East and West mere shadows of their former - united – glory, splintered by religious differences: by the holy Christ, the mighty Sol Invictus and Mithras the Lightbearer. Barbarian usurpers, claimants of all kinds, ancient enemies and would-be invaders on all sides threaten to finally extinguish its light. But Roman ambition should never be underestimated. The very same ambition that shaped the Eternal City’s birth and rise to domination is now the only thing standing between it and oblivion. The Aquila Romana, the Eagle of Rome, stands proudly at the head of the armies of all the Romans as they set forth to conquer, just as they have done a thousand times before.

The 17th descendant of Valentinian to be elected Princeps by the Senate, first among the citizens of Rome, Traianus is a shrewd and ruthless man, ready to do anything to further his ambitions. Though nowadays the authority of Rome extends no further than the city's own walls, Traianus has plans to change this. The greatest obstacles in his path are the rebels in Venetia and Neapolis, which cling to abominable heresies of Christianity and obsolete pagan traditions, and the various petty realms of the Lombard barbarians. Thanks to the recent Norman invasion, the perfect opportunity is presented to Traianus to make his move and restore Rome to it's rightful position...

Emperor of the Romans and Sol Invictus made flesh, Flavius descends from the famed Sun Emperor Julian, Saviour of the Light, much to his chagrin. Raised to be another Julian, in reality he is man beleaguered by his position, completely unsuited for the Imperial Throne. Coupled with the Empire's instability in recent years, this has led to a great crisis, as the vassal kings break away and a charismatic general from Thessalonica, claiming descent from Alexander the Great, threatens to usurp the throne and end Julian's line...

Some men trace their descent to a single famous figure, but Alexander Augustus, "August Leader" of Neapolis, descends from some of the greatest men to walk this world, with the blood of Julius Jupiter, Divus Augustus and Megas Alexandros in his veins, he is truly the son of the Divine, a fact he constantly reminds to everyone, for Alexander's ambition is only surpassed by his pomposity. In recent times, he has unilaterally declared the Senate in Rome null and void, claiming that only a man descending from the Divine Emperors and Conquerors of old can restore Rome to it's proper glory, and not a slave to the Jewish god.

Former Governor of Chaldia, and now the self-styled Despot of Trebizond, Kaisaros Konstantinian comes from the main line of Emperor Contantine's the Great descendants. Known for his irascible temperament, it his said that Kaisaros has declared independence out of anger for the state of the Empire and the general incompetence of it's officials, up to Emperor Flavius, nothing more than a pampered coward in his eyes. While he originally intended to seize the Imperial Throne, now, with the charismatic Dorotheos Argeadai in scene, Kaisaros instead plans to expand his realm north, and perhaps finally bring order to the coasts of the Black Sea...

At first sight, Lucius Aurelius is a genius the likes the world has not seen in centuries. Learned in the Classics and an accomplished statesman, he's everything a proper "philosopher king" should be. Except that deep down, Lucius is a man broken by the weight of expectation that his bloodline brings, that of the great Marcus Aurelius. A cynical man, to whom the church of Christus Sol is but another tool of the state, he is as well envious of those who have tranquiler lives. From the island-fortress of Venetia, Lucius prepares to lay claim to the whole of Rome, hoping that perhaps, succeeding in this endeavour will finally calm his inner demons...

Tiberius Severus is a man of duty before anything else. Duty to his realm, to his blood, and to Mithras, and nothing more. There's little personality beyond these facts, behind the grim and stonelike face of Tiberius. An accomplished warrior, uncharismatic, and completely disinterested for the frivolities of life, in order to maintain loyalty among his vassals, he relies on his best general, and only friend, Flavius Rodericus Vivaricus, an exile from the Gothic realms of Hispania, forever in debt to his liege for the shelter he provided from the deadly politics of the Visigoth courts. Tiberius will perhaps do anything to fulfil the duty of his bloodline, to restore Hispania for the Severans...

All the might of the Christ and Sol Invictus together could not bring down the ancient worlds of the Celts, the Germans, the Norse the Balts, the Slavs, and of many other peoples for which civilized languages have no name. In the endless plains and forests of North-Western Europe, Europa Barbarorum, the Barbaric Europe, is still very much alive, a place where the old gods still dwell. Beware, as the proud tribes who once defeated Karolus Magnus, determined to preserve their ancient customs at any cost, have adapted to use the tricks, tools and advancements of the civilized world. As the Macedonians of old had once been considered as barbaric by their southern Hellenic neighbours, the Megas Alexandros of the new era may well turn to be a leader from the Europa Barbarorum!

High King of the Britons by the grace of Zalmoxis and His champion Christ, Artorus of the Pendragon line, trueborn descendant of Lucius Artorius Castus, saviour of Britain. Though his title and blood carry little weigh nowadays, young Artorus is resolute to make the title of High King befitting of its name again. A strong believer in the honorable forms of combat and leadership, this attitude earns equal measures of recognition and derision from his subjects, who often snicker behind his back or look down on his childish ideals. Nevertheless, King Pendragon often leads his knights bravely, from the front, hoping to live up to the name of his great ancestor, and one day perhaps be worthy of his own Sword of Victory...

Karl Albrecht, most serene Kaiser, crowned by God, august and great ruler of the Sacred Roman Empire, blood of Karolus Magnus himself. This is the grandeur title by which the court officials of the Imperial Capital of Jülich will present the Sacral Emperor. In reality, the Imperial Crown is all majesty, with no power to back it up. Karl Albrecht is an old man, happy with his pitiable position and the meager occupations it brings, to receive foreign dignitaries, accept the bows, smiles and gifts and take the sons of minor nobles into his imperial guard. Jülich though, is a nest of vipers, and many of the elderly emperor’s relatives are ready to seize the Imperial Crown and further their own ambitions...

Crowned king of Francia as a young boy, the charismatic and handsome Clotaire has found it easy to charm his way through life with relative ease. Very popular with the common people thanks to his amiable personality, he has often used this as a leverage against his contentious vassals. The Merovingian dynasty was restored from obscurity in 902AD, and in a move to take revenge against the Pope and his support for the Karling as Sacral Emperors, they established their own Christian church, with the King as its absolute head, and a council of bishops running the day-to-day matters of the church. Let the usurpers tremble, for it is time for the true, holy Sang Real to rule yet again over all the Franks!

Second son of Gelimer III, youngest of age, Huneric started showing symptoms of the leper. Since the line was already safe with his elder brother, young Huneric spend his childhood sheltered in his quarters, with the tales of his mighty ancestor, King Gelimer, and other poetry epics as his only company. At age 11 he started studying military tactics under his uncle Sigeric and alongside his cousin Gelimer. When his father died of old age, Huneric plotted in order to seize Carthage from his unassuming elder brother Gaiseric. He ordered the assassination of Gaieric, and eventually executed his younger sister for her refusal to marry a political ally. Now, the Leper King is determined to fulfil the ambition of his ancestor, an Empire of all the Vandals, while his vengeful uncle, bitter over Huneric's betrayal of his family, has raised his son Gelimer in hopes to overthrow the Leper King before he leads Carthage to it's doom and to have him become the king that Huneric should have been.

Most righteous [Root.GetTitledFirstName], I have a humble request for you in light of your debt to us. There is no rest in our defense against the infidels and we have desperate need of warriors to lead our men. Thus, I would like to extend this opportunity to your able and noble son [FromFrom.GetFirstName] to serve in our ranks. Naturally, this would disinherit him. Sincerely Yours in the name of [From.Religion.GetHighGodName],\n\nGrand Master [From.GetFirstName]
column3: Très Juste [Root.GetTitledFirstName], j'ai une humble requête à vous soumettre, qui a trait à votre dette envers nous. Notre lutte contre les infidèles ne connaît pas de répit et nous avons un grand besoin de chevaliers pour mener nos hommes. Nous aimerions donc présenter l'opportunité à votre noble et talentueux fils [FromFrom.GetFirstName] de servir dans nos rangs. Naturellement, cette décision le déshériterait. Fidèlement vôtre dans le Christ,\n\nGrand Maître [From.GetFirstName]
column4: Erhabener[Root.GetTitledFirstName], angesichts der Tatsache, dass Ihr uns Geld schuldet, habe ich einen bescheidenen Wunsch an Euch. Die Abwehr gegen die Ungläubigen beschäftigt uns ständig und wir brauchen dringend Ritter als Anführer unserer Männer. Daher bitte ich um Eurem tapferen und edlen Sohn. Gelobt sei Jesus Christus! \n\nGroßmeister [From.GetFirstName]
column6: Mi justo [Root.GetTitledFirstName], tengo una humilde petición que hacerle a la luz de la deuda que mantiene con nosotros. Nuestra defensa contra los infieles no cesa y necesitamos urgentemente caballeros para dirigir a nuestros hombres. Por lo tanto, me gustaría ofrecer esta oportunidad a su noble y fuerte hijo [FromFrom.GetFirstName] para que se aliste en nuestras filas. Como bien sabe, esta acción le desheredará. Sinceramente suyo en Cristo,\n\nGran Maestre [From.GetFirstName]

Most righteous [Root.GetTitledFirstName], our order needs more castles in order to train troops and generate a supporting income. It has come to my attention that there is a suitable location in your demesne - in [FromFrom.GetName] to be specific. I am willing to pay you 100 gold in exchange for the right to construct a fortress there.
Praise [From.Religion.GetHighGodName],

Grand Master [From.GetFirstName]
column3:
Très juste [Root.GetTitledFirstName], l'Ordre a besoin de nouveaux châteaux afin de lever des troupes et de générer le revenu nécessaire à son fonctionnement. Il m'est apparu que vous possédiez un emplacement approprié sur votre domaine, en [FromFrom.GetName] pour être précis. Je suis disposé à vous payer 100 or en échange du droit d'y construire une forteresse.
Pax Christi,

Grand Maître [From.GetFirstName]
column4:
Hochwohlgeborener [Root.GetTitledFirstName], der Orden braucht weitere Burgen zur Ausbildung von Truppen und zur Erzeugung von Einnahmen. Ich habe erfahren, dass es in Eurem Reich einen geeigneten Standort gibt - nämlich in [FromFrom.GetName]. Ich will Euch 100 Gold zahlen für das Recht, dort eine Festung zu errichten.
Der Friede des Herrn sei mit Euch!

column6:
Mi justo [Root.GetTitledFirstName], la Orden necesita más castillos para entrenar tropas y obtener ingresos para sostenerse. Ha llegado a mi conocimiento que hay un lugar adecuado en su heredad, en [FromFrom.GetName] para ser más precisos. Estoy dispuesto a pagarle 100 oros a cambio del derecho a construir allí una fortaleza.
Pax Christi,

Gran Maestre [From.GetFirstName]

column2:
Your majesty, this antagonism is completely unwarranted! Our order serves [From.Religion.GetHighGodName], but, one has to wonder, do you?

With anger and sadness,

Grand Master [From.GetFirstName]
column3:
Votre Majesté, cet antagonisme est complètement injustifié ! L'Ordre sert le Christ, mais certains se posent la question : vous, le servez-vous ?

Veuillez agréer l'expression de ma colère et de ma tristesse,

Grand Maître [From.GetFirstName]
column4:
Eure Majestät, diese Ablehung ist völlig ungerechtfertigt! Unser Orden dient dem Herrn, doch man muss sich fragen, tut Ihr das auch?

In Zorn und Trauer,

Großmeister [From.GetFirstName]
column6:
Su majestad, ¡este antagonismo es totalmente injustificado! La Orden sirve a Cristo, pero cabe preguntarse, ¿y usted?

Con ira y tristeza,

Gran Maestre [From.GetFirstName]

column3: Votre Altesse, ce don des plus généreux ne sera pas oublié. Recevez mon amitié ainsi que celle de l'Église. Vivez avec l'assurance que vous obtiendrez récompense au paradis, si ce n'est en ce bas monde ! Pax Christi,\n\nGrand Maître [From.GetFirstName]
column4:
Eure Hoheit, diese äußerst großzügige Spende wird unvergessen bleiben! Ihr habt meine Freundschaft, wie auch die der Kirche! Seid versichert, dass Ihr im Himmel belohnt werdet, wenn nicht schon auf Erden! 
Der Friede des Herrn sei mit Euch!

Großmeister [From.GetFirstName]
column6:
Su Alteza, esta donación tan generosa no caerá en el olvido. Tiene mi amistad, así como la de la Iglesia. Tenga por seguro que será recompensado en el cielo, ¡si no en la Tierra!
Pax Christi,

Gran Maestre [From.GetFirstName]

column2: The sonnet's poetic expression of both the pain of separation and the beauty of love in spite of that pain is the perfect poetic form for my next song!
column3: Le genre littéraire appelé ghazal, expression de la douleur et de la séparation, ainsi que de la beauté de l'amour, est un style poétique parfait pour ma prochaine chanson !
column4: Der poetische Audruck des Ghazal, sowohl des Trennungsschmerzes als auch der Schönheit der Liebe ungeachtet des Schmerzes, ist die perfekte poetische Form für mein nächstes Lied!
column6: El ghazal, por su expresión poética, es la forma perfecta para mi próxima canción. Refleja tanto el dolor de la separación como la belleza del amor a pesar del sufrimiento.
